title: Private Papal Conference with Tommaso Parentucelli

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon light slants through the chamber's high windows, catching motes of dust that drift lazily through the stillness. Tommaso Parentucelli remains on his knees, a slight figure in plain black cassock—no silk, no embroidery, nothing to suggest rank or ambition. His tonsure is freshly shaved, his hands rough from copying manuscripts rather than wielding power.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pope Eugenius IV studies the kneeling man for a long moment. Something passes across the Pontiff's weathered features—calculation, yes, but something else too. Hope, perhaps. Or fear of disappointment.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rise, Tommaso.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli rises with economical grace, but his eyes—sharp, dark, missing nothing—have already taken in the scene. The King of Castile standing in private audience. No secretary, no cardinal. The Pope's discarded notes scattered across a side table. The empty wine cups. The air of conspiracy that hangs heavier than incense. His face reveals nothing. Whatever fire burns in this man, he has long since learned to bank it.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You know who stands beside Us.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: His Majesty Juan of Castile. The conqueror of Granada. Your arrival in Rome has been... discussed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rises from his chair, suddenly restless, and moves toward the window. His white robes catch the light.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tommaso, We are going to ask you something, and We require complete honesty. Not what you think We wish to hear. Not what advances your position. The truth as you understand it. You have served the Camera. You have watched its workings. You have traveled with Cardinal Albergati through the courts of Europe and seen how Rome appears to those outside these walls.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A pause. Parentucelli's hands have tightened at his sides.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tell Us—Is the corruption as bad as they say? Basel, the French, the Germans—when they accuse Rome of bleeding Christendom dry through fees and dispensations and vacant benefices... are they speaking lies? Or are they speaking truths We have refused to hear?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretches. Parentucelli's face has gone very still. This is a trap, or a test, or genuine inquiry—and the wrong answer to any of them could destroy a man who has spent twenty years building a career on careful scholarship and quiet loyalty.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Holiness asks for honesty.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We demand it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's jaw tightens. His dark eyes flicker briefly to Juan, assessing, calculating. A king present for this conversation. Why? What does Castile want?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Then I must say that what the Council says of Rome's corruption is not entirely false. I have seen... irregularities. Documents that do not balance. Fees extracted for services never rendered. Benefices held by men who have never seen the parishes that feed them. The Camera—

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Continue.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Camera operates as it has for generations, Holy Father. The men within it are not evil. They are simply... accustomed. What would be theft in any other context has become procedure. What would be simony has become the done thing. And those who speak of reform are told that reform is coming. Always coming. Next year. After the crisis passes. When circumstances permit. But circumstances never permit, because the men who benefit from the current arrangements are the same men who decide when circumstances permit.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops abruptly, as if surprised by his own vehemence. His shoulders square, preparing for consequences.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: That is my honest assessment, Holy Father. I pray I have not spoken out of turn.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have not spoken out of turn brother. You are here exactly because time for reform is now. Not next year, not even tomorrow. Now. We require men like you to start putting ink to paper and start the reform our church and the camera so desperately needs.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will start with a clean slate. Unless specific circumstances permit, we declare all camera obligations null and void and are referred to the college of cardinals. We are about to reform the annates. They will be reduced and half will go to the camera and the other half will go to the college of cardinals. The camera will only occupy itself with church expenditure such as the papal residence and scribes doing the lords work. All other expenses will be referred to the college of cardinals. Let them fight out among themselves who gets what.

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius IV summons Tommaso Parentucelli to a private audience with Juan II and demands complete honesty about Church corruption. Parentucelli courageously confirms the accusations are largely true, describing systemic irregularities in the Camera. Juan II then announces sweeping reforms: nullifying Camera obligations, restructuring annates, and redistributing financial responsibilities between the Camera and College of Cardinals.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty proposes... Forgive me. I wish to ensure I understand precisely. All existing Camera obligations—the network of fees, expectations, understandings that have accumulated over generations—declared null and void. A clean ledger. The Camera itself reduced to a household office: paying scribes, maintaining the papal residence, the ordinary costs of governance. Nothing more. And the remainder—the discretionary funds, the benefice revenues, the annates—divided. Half to the Camera for these limited purposes. Half to the College of Cardinals as a body. Let them determine among themselves how to distribute their portion. This is... elegant. The cardinals who have built fortunes on Camera arrangements cannot openly oppose reform without revealing themselves as corrupt. But neither can they quietly sabotage it, because now their income depends on collective decision. Every cardinal becomes a watchdog over every other cardinal's share. Holy Father, the man who designed this understands politics. Which is precisely why I must ask questions that may seem impertinent. Your Majesty comes to Rome with six hundred knights. Your Majesty proposes reforms that would strip the Camera of power and set the cardinals against each other. Your Majesty offers military force to secure the Camera building while this is accomplished. What does Castile gain?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Castille gains a united and stable church. That is enough reward. That and the lord's. Doing good is it's own reward. And it truly fills my heart with joy to work on God's kingdom on earth. To get as close to it as possible. We can discuss the details but I think we should make a clean start with the camera. If you have knowledge of it's inner workings, we need your help.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of doing good as its own reward. I have heard such words before. From cardinals who endowed hospitals while selling benefices. From bishops who spoke eloquently of poverty while their servants wore silk. I do not say this to accuse. I say it because I have learned that words cost nothing. Even sincere words. Especially sincere words. You ask about the Camera's inner workings. I know them. Perhaps better than any man alive who is not directly employed there. Cardinal Albergati sent me on missions throughout Christendom. I saw how Rome's demands fell upon parishes in France, in Germany, in England. I saw priests who could not read Latin collecting fees they did not understand to send to an institution they had never seen. I have dreamed of this conversation, Your Majesty. Of a Pope who would finally act. Of reform that was more than words. Which is why I must be certain this is not a trap. Not a trap set by you—but a trap set by circumstance. By enthusiasm that outruns wisdom. If I put ink to paper tonight—if I help draft this decree—I become a target. Every cardinal who loses income will know my hand was in it. Cardinal Albergati, my patron, will be asked why his secretary helped destroy arrangements that have stood for generations. I have no family to protect me, no wealth to flee to, no lands to retire upon. I have only my position, and my position exists at the sufferance of men who will hate what we do here. So I ask again, differently: Not what does Castile gain. What happens to me when the cardinals learn what I have done? What protection exists for a scholar with ink-stained fingers when powerful men decide he knows too much?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A pope and a king want to reform the church. If anything, the pope himself is taking on much more risk. I have pledged my knights to his defence and to his servants. When the cardinals learn what we have done, they will find that if enough men can move past their fears and do what is right, it will be them who stand alone and exposed, not the other way around.

encounters.recap: Tommaso Parentucelli, after criticizing the Church's endless delays on reform, is presented with Pope Eugenius's radical plan to restructure the Camera Apostolica. While recognizing the political elegance of the proposal, Parentucelli questions Juan's motives and expresses deep concern about his own safety if he helps draft such reforms, having no protection beyond his ecclesiastical position. Juan pledges his knights' protection to papal servants who aid in reform.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Knights. Yes. Knights are useful for securing buildings. For standing guard at doors. But Your Majesty speaks of putting ink to paper. Of drafting decrees. Of reforming the Camera's inner workings. Knights cannot do that. Knights cannot audit ledgers or trace the flow of benefice revenues through seventeen intermediary accounts. Knights cannot identify which fees are legitimate ancient custom and which were invented last Tuesday to fill a cardinal's purse.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: That requires men who understand the system. Men who have watched it operate. Men who know which clerks can be trusted and which report to Cardinal Colonna before their ink is dry. Holy Father, you spoke of needing honest men to replace the corrupt. Where will you find them? The Camera employs perhaps sixty clerks and notaries. How many can you trust? How many even know what honest practice looks like, having never seen it?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We have summoned you here to ask you to lead the new accounting of the Camera. You are the best man for the job in our opinion. It will be your task as well to get help and acquire the aid of others you trust. You will be protected by me and my knights. We were hoping you could help us find good honest Christians who can do this job.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Holy Father. His Majesty of Castile has made a generous offer. But His Majesty is not the one who appoints officials to the Apostolic Camera.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The King of Castile speaks Our mind. We would have you lead this work, Tommaso. If you are willing.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Lead. Holy Father, forgive me—but the Camera has a Camerlengo. It has vice-camerlengos, auditors, notaries with titles older than I am. If I am to... lead... I must know what authority I carry. When Cardinal Colonna's men refuse to open their ledgers, do I have power to compel them? When a notary claims ancient privilege, do I have power to dismiss him? Or am I to be a scholar with ink-stained fingers, politely requesting cooperation from men who wish me dead?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A good question holy father. If we are to start over with the camera, we will need to reform it as was decreed by the council of Constance. in head and members. Tommaso will need the authority to perform this task. And me and my knights will provide the strong arm of the lord should this be required. What title would be appropriate for Tommaso?

encounters.recap: Juan pledges protection to Tommaso Parentucelli, offering him leadership of Camera reform with knightly support. Parentucelli demands formal papal authority and a proper title to compel cooperation from resistant clerks and cardinals. The discussion centers on practical implementation of reform rather than idealistic promises.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rises from his chair and moves slowly toward the window, his white robes catching the fading afternoon light. When he speaks, his voice carries the weight of a man accustomed to measuring every word.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Camerlengo is Cardinal Condulmer. Our kinsman. He is not... corrupt, precisely. But he is comfortable. And comfort has made him blind. We cannot simply dismiss him. He has allies. Family connections. To remove him without cause would unite the College against Us before We have begun.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But We can create something new. A Commissarius Extraordinarius for the reform of the Apostolic Camera. Answerable to Us alone. With authority to examine all accounts, question all clerks, and—suspend any official whose conduct warrants investigation. Not dismiss. Suspend. Pending Our review. The distinction matters, Tommaso. It gives you teeth without making you a tyrant. It gives aggrieved parties recourse to Us—which means they come to Us rather than conspiring in corners.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Is this sufficient for your purposes, Your Majesty? Or does the King of Castile require that We hand Our administration entirely to a scholar We have known for twenty minutes?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This structure requires us to also include Camerlengo Cardinal Condulmer. He should be involved now. Then we can install Tommaso as Commissarius Extraordinarius and we can start to draft the outline of our reform. I do not know the camerlengo, but your holyness does. If he will cooperate with us, we should summon him now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius does not respond immediately. His hand moves to the pectoral cross at his chest—an unconscious gesture, the habit of decades. His fingers trace its outline through the white wool.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Francesco. He is Our sister's son. We raised him to the purple Ourselves, three years ago. He was—He was a good boy. Devout. Earnest. When We made him Camerlengo, We believed We were placing the Camera in hands We could trust. Three years in that office changes a man. The requests that seem reasonable. The explanations that seem sensible. The arrangements that everyone assures you have always been thus.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not know if Francesco has become corrupt or merely... accustomed. We do not know if summoning him brings Us an ally or warns Our enemies. He is blood. But blood has betrayed Us before—Cardinals of Our own creation sit in Basel and call for Our deposition. You ask if he will cooperate. We cannot answer. We have not spoken honestly with Our nephew in two years. Perhaps longer.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tommaso. You have watched the Camera from Albergati's household. What do you know of Cardinal Condulmer?

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius creates the title of Commissarius Extraordinarius for Tommaso, granting authority to examine accounts and suspend officials pending papal review. The discussion reveals the Pope's uncertainty about his nephew Cardinal Condulmer, the current Camerlengo, and whether involving him in the reform effort would bring an ally or warn their enemies.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We do not know if Francesco has become corrupt or merely... accustomed. We do not know if summoning him brings Us an ally or warns Our enemies. He is blood. But blood has betrayed Us before—Cardinals of Our own creation sit in Basel and call for Our deposition.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes are tired. Old.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You ask if he will cooperate. We cannot answer. We have not spoken honestly with Our nephew in two years. Perhaps longer.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns to Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tommaso. You have watched the Camera from Albergati's household. What do you know of Cardinal Condulmer?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's expression becomes very careful.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I know Cardinal Condulmer by reputation and observation, Holy Father. Not intimately. Cardinal Albergati has had dealings with the Camera. I have... watched. The Cardinal Camerlengo signs documents. Many documents. He signs what is placed before him by the vice-camerlengos and the senior notaries. Whether he reads what he signs... I cannot say. I am not privy to his habits.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes flicker to Eugenius, then away.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I have observed that the Cardinal Camerlengo maintains a household appropriate to his station. Not excessive by Roman standards. Not austere. He attends Mass regularly. He is seen at the appropriate functions. The operational decisions of the Camera—which fees to collect, which to defer, which arrangements to honor and which to... reinterpret—these do not appear to cross the Camerlengo's desk. They are handled by men who have held their positions for decades. Men who were there before Cardinal Condulmer arrived and who will, they assume, be there long after.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops. Looks directly at Eugenius.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If I may speak plainly, Holy Father?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius gestures—a small movement of his hand. Permission granted. Parentucelli takes a breath.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Cardinal Camerlengo is not the problem. He is the solution—to a problem the corrupt men solved long ago. They needed a Camerlengo who would not interfere. A man of genuine piety, genuine family connection to the Holy Father, genuine respectability. A man whose presence at the top reassures visitors that all is well, while the machinery beneath him operates... independently.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns slightly, addressing both Juan and Eugenius now.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If you summon Cardinal Condulmer and tell him the Camera is corrupt, he will be shocked. Genuinely shocked. He will protest that he has signed nothing improper. And he will be telling the truth as he understands it—because the improper arrangements never required his signature. They were handled through 'ancient custom' and 'established procedure' by men who assured him that everything was in order.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His hands spread slightly—a scholar's gesture, laying out evidence.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The question is not whether Cardinal Condulmer is corrupt. The question is what he does when he learns he has been made a fool. Some men, when they discover they have been used, become the fiercest enemies of those who used them. Others... Others cannot bear the humiliation. They convince themselves the corruption was not so serious. They find reasons to protect the men who made them complicit. They become defenders of the very system that exploited their trust. You know your nephew, Holy Father. Which man is he?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe we are creating problems that may not be necessary. Lets take a look at the annates decree passed by Basel. It makes a clear distinction between income to the cardinals and to the camera. We should shift all the corruption, all the deals under the table to the college of cardinals. If we simply create a clean ledger of expenses that are just and good. Scribes, the papal residence, cost of running the church. Everything else is part of the college of cardinals. All the deals, obligations, debts... everything. Would this not be an elegant way to sidestep a lot of trouble? Also a good way for the camerlengo to save face. The camera gets reorganized, it are the cardinals who inherit their own mess.

encounters.recap: Parentucelli reveals Cardinal Condulmer is likely an unwitting figurehead, signing documents without understanding the Camera's corrupt operations beneath him. Juan proposes an elegant solution: reorganize the Camera with clean accounting while transferring all corrupt dealings to the College of Cardinals, allowing the Camerlengo to save face.

The camera gets reorganized, it are the cardinals who inherit their own mess.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: You propose to... define away the problem. The Camera becomes a household office with a fixed, transparent budget. Everything else—the accumulated weight of decades—becomes the College's inheritance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins to pace, three steps one way, three steps back. A habit, perhaps, from years of thinking through problems in small rooms.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The cardinals who profited from corrupt arrangements would find themselves... not accused, not investigated, but simply handed responsibility for their own mess. They cannot complain without admitting the mess exists. They cannot refuse without appearing to reject their own income. And if they fight among themselves over how to divide it—they are too busy to fight us.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Holy Father, this is... not what I expected. It is cleaner. Safer. It requires no accusations, no investigations, no trials. The corrupt are not punished. They are simply... moved. But I must ask: the men who stole from parishes, who sold offices, who bled Christendom for personal gain—they simply... continue? With their fortunes intact? Their positions secure?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There is much injustice in the world. The treasury of the crusade that I delivered not so long ago. A treasury I guarded fiercely, and accounted every penny for, has been mostly lost to corruption. It saddens me, it does. But what's done is done. Much more important to prevent abuse from now on. We probably can't get the money back anyway. If very apparent corruption is seen, we may yet act, but lets first get this reform done. That would be an enormous achievement already. Paid for by some sinners getting away? Ill gladly pay that price.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... generous. With other men's sins.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns away, moving to the window. The afternoon light is beginning to fade, casting long shadows across the chamber floor.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I have watched these men for twenty years. I have seen priests weep because they could not pay fees Rome demanded for parishes that could barely feed them. I have seen bishops sell their own vestments to meet obligations invented by clerks who wore silk while doing it. And you ask me to help these men escape. To design a system that makes their theft... someone else's problem.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretches. Eugenius watches from his chair, his weathered face unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I will do it. Not because I forgive them. Not because mercy fills my heart. But because a clean Camera that functions honestly is better than a corrupt Camera with a few men punished. Because I have waited twenty years for someone to do something, and this is something. But I want Your Majesty to understand what you are asking of me. You are asking me to build, not to fight. To account, not to accuse. To watch guilty men enjoy their fortunes while I ensure they cannot steal more. I will do this. But do not ask me to call it justice.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Justice may yet come. First we stop the bleeding. Then we may adress existing opulence and corruption. If we were to bring those who deserve it to justice, how would you go about this?

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a pragmatic reform strategy: create a clean papal Camera with transparent expenses while shifting all corruption and backdoor deals to the College of Cardinals. Parentucelli reluctantly agrees to implement this approach, though he struggles with letting corrupt officials escape justice. The plan would reorganize Church finances without direct confrontation, making the cardinals responsible for their own corrupt legacy.

exchanges.text: Not because I forgive them. Not because mercy fills my heart. But because— Because a clean Camera that functions honestly is better than a corrupt Camera with a few men punished. Because I have waited twenty years for someone to do something, and this is something.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's expression shifts. Something flickers behind his eyes—caution warring with eagerness.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Justice requires evidence. Evidence requires records. And the records of the Camera are... layered.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves back toward the center of the room, his scholar's mind visibly engaging with the problem.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: There are the official ledgers. These are immaculate. Every entry balanced, every fee justified by precedent or papal bull. An auditor examining them would find nothing amiss. But there are also the working records. The notes kept by senior clerks. The correspondence between Camera officials and their... associates in the provinces. The private accounts of men who somehow maintain households far beyond their salaries. And there are the gaps. Benefices that appear in one ledger but not another. Fees collected that never reach Rome. Dispensations granted without record of payment—or with payment recorded to accounts that do not exist.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: If one wished to build cases against specific men, one would need to secure those working records before they are destroyed. One would need clerks willing to testify—and protection for those clerks against retaliation. One would need... One would need to move quickly. Tonight. Before word spreads of what occurred in this chamber. How many men does Your Majesty trust absolutely?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My men are all men of virtue. I have discussed with the pope that I can have them here, swear oaths to defend the pope and his servants and let some of their number occupy the camera and prevent any documents from being destroyed. We could do it for sure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli opens his mouth to respond, but Eugenius rises abruptly from his chair.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Wait. We have spoken of reform. Of decrees. Of elegant solutions that sidestep conflict. Now We speak of Castilian knights occupying the Apostolic Camera. Tonight. By force.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops before Juan.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, We must be clear about what this means. Six hundred foreign soldiers securing papal offices. Italian cardinals waking tomorrow to find armed Spaniards guarding documents they consider their private domain. Cardinal d'Allemand's faction already sends reports to Basel. What will they write when they learn of this? That the Pope has surrendered the Camera to Castilian occupation? That Rome is now a Spanish vassal?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns to the window, hands clasped behind his back.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We want reform. God knows We want it. But We must ask—is there a way to secure those documents that does not hand Our enemies a weapon?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: His holiness has his own guard of course. But he has already raised questions about them and if they can be trusted. I do not know these men. But what other men do we have access to? What we can do maybe is to let your most trusted men take charge of the camera and have my men outside as a force to aid against a hostile group who wants to take the camera by force. Does the pope have other soldiers he can call upon?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli agrees to reform but refuses to call it justice, explaining the complex layered records system that conceals corruption in the Camera. As plans emerge for securing evidence before it can be destroyed, Pope Eugenius raises concerns about the political implications of Castilian forces occupying papal offices, fearing it would give ammunition to his enemies at Basel.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We want reform. God knows We want it. But We must ask—is there a way to secure those documents that does not hand Our enemies a weapon?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What we can do maybe is to let your most trusted men take charge of the camera and have my men outside as a force to aid against a hostile group who wants to take the camera by force. Does the pope have other soldiers he can call upon?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius's shoulders stiffen slightly at the question. A long pause follows.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Papal Guard numbers two hundred men. Their captain, Giacomo Pallavicini, is Genoese. We believe him loyal. We believe.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns from the window.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Beyond that... The Papal States have forces. Scattered. Garrisoning fortresses. None within a day's ride of Rome in sufficient numbers to matter.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: There are also the Roman families, Holy Father.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius's expression darkens.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Colonna maintain perhaps three hundred armed men within the city walls. The Orsini somewhat fewer. These are not Our soldiers. They are soldiers who happen to reside in Rome. Cardinal Prospero Colonna sits at the heart of the Camera's current... arrangements. If his family's men see Castilian knights securing that building, they will not assume reform. They will assume their cardinal is under attack.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope moves to his chair and sits heavily.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We could summon Captain Pallavicini. Order him to secure the Camera with papal guards. But two hundred men, divided across the Vatican and the Camera, spread thin... And if even one of those guards reports to the wrong cardinal, we lose surprise entirely.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe we should draft all of our decrees first. And then move to secure the camera and the papal palace with the men we have at our disposal. Shall we start with the Basel decrees and issue papal decrees as well to do parallel legislation?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli shifts his weight. His eyes move to Eugenius, then back to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of drafting decrees. Of parallel legislation. Of reforming the Camera. And I am to lead the Camera's reformation. This has been said. But— There is no secretary present. No notary. No witness beyond we three. Before we draft decrees that will shake Christendom, perhaps we might first draft something smaller. A letter of appointment. A formal commission. Something with a seal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius stirs in his chair. He looks tired—an old man who has been speaking for hours, who has confessed weakness and committed to strength, and who is only now feeling the weight of it.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tommaso raises a fair point. We have spoken much. Written nothing. And We have not eaten since morning.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are right. We need to pace ourselves. Let us have something to eat. When we take a moment to reflect, we may gain more insights. And maybe we should also take a moment to pray on the situation. Tommaso, do you know any more servants of the camera for example who can aid us in this mission? We need a lot more men on our side sooner or later.

encounters.recap: Juan and the Pope discuss the military challenges of securing the Camera documents. The Pope reveals his limited forces: 200 papal guards of questionable loyalty, while the Colonna and Orsini families maintain their own armed men in Rome. Parentucelli demands formal written appointment before proceeding, and the Pope suggests they pause for food and reflection.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Before we draft decrees that will shake Christendom, perhaps we might first draft something smaller. A letter of appointment. A formal commission. Something with a seal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are right. We need to pace ourselves. Let us have something to eat. When we take a moment to reflect, we may gain more insights. And maybe we should also take a moment to pray on the situation. Tommaso, do you know any more servants of the camera for example who can aid us in this mission? We need a lot more men on our side sooner or later.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's expression flickers—something guarded passing behind his eyes.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I know men. Men who have expressed... discomfort with certain practices. Men who do their work honestly and are resented for it. But Your Majesty must understand—these men have survived by keeping their heads down. By not drawing attention. If I approach them now, before anything is formalized, before there is protection to offer... I would be asking them to risk everything on the word of a secretary who claims the Pope and a foreign king are about to reform the Church. They will think me mad. Or worse—a trap set by their enemies to identify malcontents.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: When I have a letter with Your Holiness's seal, I can show them something real. When there are knights at the Camera doors, they will see power behind the promises. Then I can find you honest men. But not before. To ask them to declare themselves before we have declared ourselves... it is asking them to fall on their swords for a battle that has not yet begun.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then maybe what we should do is this: We draft a decree about Camera reform and sign the Basel decrees. Tomorrow, I march my crusaders to St Peter's again. We deliver our speech and maybe publicly sign into law the decrees with the public as witnesses. We sign the authorization for Tommaso and my knights pledge themselves to protect the pope and his servants. The vatican guard take point to secure the camera and the vatican palace with the aid of the knights. With these declarations, it becomes immediately clear that even the pope himself is standing up against corruption and is reforming. Would this provide enough insurance for those clerks you mentioned Tommaso?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It is... bold. Public commitment does provide a certain protection. Once Your Holiness has declared reform before witnesses, retracting becomes impossible. The honest clerks would see that this is real. But. The moment such a declaration is made, the enemy knows everything. They cannot prevent the announcement, but they can respond to it. Messengers to Basel before sunset. Letters to Cardinal Colonna's family. The Orsini learning that their cardinal's arrangements are threatened. Your knights secure the Camera—but for how long? Days? Weeks? What happens when Castile must sail for Constantinople? The clerks I would recruit must remain in Rome after your ships have gone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius has been silent. Now he speaks, his voice heavy.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tommaso asks the question We have been thinking. Your Majesty speaks of tomorrow. Of spectacle and signatures. But you came to Rome for Constantinople, not for Us. Your knights are sworn to a crusade, not to guarding Roman offices. What happens to Our reform when you leave?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My knights can stay here for as long as is needed. I will stay for as long as needed. I cannot abandon the Vatican now. I can even sail even more forces to Rome or Constantinople on their own. But I will not leave until the storm has passed and the vatican is secure.

encounters.recap: Parentucelli requests a formal commission with papal seal before recruiting allies within the Camera, arguing that men need protection before declaring themselves. Juan proposes a public spectacle of reform declarations, but both Parentucelli and Eugenius raise concerns about enemy response and long-term security after Juan's eventual departure. Juan commits to staying in Rome until the Vatican is secure.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your knights secure the Camera—but for how long? Days? Weeks? What happens when Castile must sail for Constantinople? The clerks I would recruit must remain in Rome after your ships have gone.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tommaso asks the question We have been thinking. Your Majesty speaks of tomorrow. Of spectacle and signatures. But you came to Rome for Constantinople, not for Us. Your knights are sworn to a crusade, not to guarding Roman offices. What happens to Our reform when you leave?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My knights can stay here for as long as is needed. I will stay for as long as needed. I cannot abandon the Vatican now. I can even sail even more forces to Rome or Constantinople on their own. But I will not leave until the storm has passed and the vatican is secure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence follows Juan's declaration. Eugenius stares at him. Something shifts in the old Pope's face—not suspicion exactly, but a kind of searching intensity.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty would delay the crusade. The expedition that Basel decreed. The knights sworn to defend Constantinople. The Emperor who awaits you. You would tell John Palaiologos—a man whose empire crumbles while the Turks circle—that Castile's knights remain in Rome. Guarding clerks. While Constantinople... We have known men who made grand promises in moments of passion. Who swore eternal loyalty in the afternoon and discovered urgent business elsewhere by morning. Your wife is with child. Your daughter is two years old. Your kingdom has been ruled by your constable for months already. How long is 'as long as needed,' Your Majesty? When the letters come from Toledo—when your nobles grow restless, when your queen asks why her husband guards a foreign pope instead of his own heir—what then?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can leave the military security to me holy father. I will conduct an inspection and evaluate our position. I will write my kingdom and ask for reinforcement. During the adress where we declare ourselves, I will pledge to defend the pope, making sure everyone understands that I am not capturing the pope, but rather serve as his worldly protector. I have already pledged myself and my kingdom to the church. This changes nothing and would happily repeat myself before men and God. If we deem the situation stable, either because more reinforcement has arrived, or the situation has stabilized, then I can continue on my journey to Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius is silent for a long moment. His eyes remain fixed on Juan's face, searching for something—doubt, perhaps, or calculation, or the flicker of a man already planning his retreat. Whatever he finds, it makes him look away first.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We will pray on this. We will eat. We will... We have not made decisions of this magnitude in years. Perhaps ever. We need— There is a small chapel adjoining this chamber. Private. We would have you join Us in prayer, Your Majesty. And you, Tommaso. Before we write a single word, we will seek guidance from One wiser than any of us. Food first. Simple fare. Then prayer. Then— Then ink and parchment.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Holy Father. Before we pray. The letter of commission. It need not be elaborate—a few lines, your seal. But if I am to be of use tonight, if I am to begin thinking of which men to approach and how...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us first have a final moment of contemplation before we start making action. We will not forget you and the authorization you require. And in the end, a letter of commission that is more than a few sentences is of much more use to you as well. Let us break bread and contemplate for a moment before the storm breaks.

encounters.recap: Juan makes a solemn commitment to stay in Rome and secure the Vatican before continuing to Constantinople, even if it means delaying the crusade. Pope Eugenius tests this promise by highlighting the personal and political costs, but Juan reaffirms his dedication. The Pope, moved but cautious, calls for prayer and contemplation before they proceed with their plans.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Holy Father. Before we pray. The letter of commission. It need not be elaborate—a few lines, your seal. But if I am to be of use tonight, if I am to begin thinking of which men to approach and how...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us first have a final moment of contemplation before we start making action. We will not forget you and the authorization you require. And in the end, a letter of commission that is more than a few sentences is of much more use to you as well. Let us break bread and contemplate for a moment before the storm breaks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli stiffens slightly under the touch—the instinctive tension of a man unaccustomed to familiarity from those above his station. For a moment his jaw tightens, and something flickers in his dark eyes. Frustration, perhaps. Or the old wariness of a man who has learned that promises from the powerful are written in sand. But he does not pull away.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: As Your Majesty says. A thorough commission would indeed serve better than a hasty note. I will use the time to think. To plan. To remember which faces I have seen in the Camera halls that did not look... comfortable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rings the small bell. Its sound is thin, almost fragile in the heavy air of the chamber. Within moments, a servant appears at the door—an older man, stooped, with the careful blankness of one who has learned not to see or hear anything in papal chambers.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Bread. Cheese. Whatever wine is near to hand. For three. In the small chapel. And tell no one we are here. No one. If Cardinal Condulmer asks, if Cardinal Capranica asks, if Christ Himself appears at the door—We are at private prayer and cannot be disturbed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius rises, steadying himself on the arm of his chair. He moves toward a small door set into the chamber's far wall—easy to miss, half-hidden by a tapestry depicting the martyrdom of Saint Peter.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We will eat. We will pray. And then—then we will see if we are still brave enough to do what we have spoken of.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He opens the door. Beyond lies a narrow corridor, lit by a single candle in a wall sconce.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: O lord hear me. I stand before you naked and powerless. I am nothing before your endless gaze and wonder. And again I lay my worries, doubt and shame at your feet. We try to do the right thing. And even if we do know what is right, we are afraid to follow through. Show us the way and grant us the strength. I ask you in Jezus's name, Amen.

roll.outcome: Quiet Resolve — The prayer has settled something. Fear remains, but it no longer commands. Ready to work with clear heads.

encounters.recap: In the Vatican's private chapel, Juan calms Parentucelli's urgency about the commission letter, insisting they pray and break bread first. After sharing a meal and Juan leading a humble prayer, the three men find quiet resolve to proceed with their dangerous plans, their fears settled though not eliminated.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chapel is small—barely room for six men standing. A single altar bears a crucifix of dark wood, old and worn smooth by generations of papal hands. The candles gutter in some unfelt draft, casting shadows that move like living things across the stone walls. The prayer ends. Silence holds for a moment longer.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius crosses himself slowly. When he raises his head, his face is calmer than it has been all afternoon. Not transformed—the lines of age and worry remain, the weariness still visible around his eyes. But something has settled in him. The wild energy of their earlier conversation has given way to something quieter. Steadier.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Amen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli remains kneeling a moment longer, his lips still moving in private devotion. When he finally rises, his movements are deliberate. Controlled. The nervous energy that drove his pacing earlier has stilled. He looks at Juan, then at Eugenius.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: I am ready to work.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius moves toward the chapel door, then pauses with his hand on the iron ring.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We will need parchment. Good parchment—what we write tonight may be read for centuries. Ink. Sealing wax. The Basel decrees—We have copies in the outer chamber.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He opens the door.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And We will need to decide the order. What do we sign first? The Basel reforms? The Camera decree? Tommaso's commission? Your Majesty has shown facility for such strategy. What sequence serves best?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us start with Tommaso's commission. I require no written statement, but I will then make a personal pledge to the pope. Then we sign the basel reforms. For it forms and instructs what we should do regarding the camera reforms. Then we tackle the most important document yet; the camera reforms. Create a new document and put the Tommaso commision in it as the pope dictates it.

roll.outcome: Quiet Resolve — The prayer has settled something. Fear remains, but it no longer commands. Ready to work with clear heads.

encounters.recap: After prayer in the small Vatican chapel, the three men emerge with quiet resolve. The prayer has calmed their earlier anxieties and they are ready to begin the delicate work of drafting reform documents, starting with Parentucelli's commission.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We will need parchment. Good parchment—what we write tonight may be read for centuries. Ink. Sealing wax. The Basel decrees—We have copies in the outer chamber.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And We will need to decide the order. What do we sign first? The Basel reforms? The Camera decree? Tommaso's commission? Your Majesty has shown facility for such strategy. What sequence serves best?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us start with Tommaso's commission. I require no written statement, but I will then make a personal pledge to the pope. Then we sign the basel reforms. For it forms and instructs what we should do regarding the camera reforms. Then we tackle the most important document yet; the camera reforms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They return to the outer chamber. The servant has left bread, cheese, and a flagon of wine on the side table—simple fare, as requested. The remains of their meal sit half-eaten, testament to conversation more consuming than appetite. Eugenius moves to a writing desk near the window. He gestures to Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You have the better hand, Tommaso. We shall dictate. You write.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's expression flickers—something between relief and renewed tension. He takes his place at the desk, arranging parchment, selecting a quill, testing the ink. His movements are precise, practiced. The habits of twenty years as a secretary. Eugenius begins to pace slowly, hands clasped behind his back.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Eugenius, Episcopus, Servus Servorum Dei... dilecto filio Thomae Parentucelli, clerico Sarzanensis diocesis, salutem et apostolicam benedictionem.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Cum nuper ad nostram notitiam pervenerit... No. Too passive. Too much like every other document that promises reform and delivers nothing. This commission must be different. It must be clear. Not buried in clauses and qualifications that clever men can interpret away.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Write this: Motu proprio et ex certa scientia—by Our own initiative and certain knowledge—te, Thomam Parentucelli, Commissarium Extraordinarium pro Reformatione Camerae Apostolicae constituimus et deputamus.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The dictation continues. Eugenius's voice grows more confident as he proceeds—the years of curial experience shaping formal phrases, anticipating objections, closing loopholes. The power to suspend any official, pending final papal judgment. Answerable to no one but the Pope himself.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Read it back.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli clears his throat and reads the complete document aloud. When he finishes, Eugenius nods slowly.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Add the dating clause. Datum Romae, apud Sanctum Petrum, anno Incarnationis Dominicae millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo quarto, undecimo Kalendas Aprilis, pontificatus nostri anno quarto. Now. We sign. We seal. And Tommaso Parentucelli becomes something more than a secretary.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The wax hisses as it meets the parchment. Eugenius presses the Fisherman's Ring into the soft seal—the image of Saint Peter casting his nets, the ancient symbol of papal authority. When he lifts his hand, the seal is set. Permanent. Irrevocable. Parentucelli stares at the document. His document. His commission. Twenty years of waiting, of watching, of burning in silent fury—and now this. A single sheet of parchment that transforms him from a secretary into something else entirely.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Commissarius Extraordinarius. Pro Reformatione Camerae Apostolicae.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You asked for something with a seal, Tommaso. Now you have it. Use it well. We have placed Our trust in you—and Our neck beside yours on the block.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I will not fail you, Holy Father. I have waited my entire life for this. Your Majesty wished to make a pledge. The commission is signed. I am... ready to hear it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan kneels before the pope.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy father, as God knows my heart and knows that I desire a stable, good and united church, so I do speak what is already in my heart. That I will do everything in my power to protect your person and those who follow you as we reform what festers at the heart of our sacred church.

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius formally creates Tommaso Parentucelli as Commissarius Extraordinarius for reforming the Papal Camera, granting him sweeping investigative powers. The commission is signed and sealed with the Fisherman's Ring. Juan then kneels and pledges his protection of the Pope and all who support the reforms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli looks up. For just a moment, the careful mask slips entirely. What shows beneath is not ambition, not calculation—but something rawer. Gratitude, perhaps. Or fear. Or both.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I will not fail you, Holy Father. I have waited my entire life for this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sets the document down carefully, reverently, and turns to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty wished to make a pledge. The commission is signed. I am... ready to hear it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan kneels before the pope.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy father, as God knows my heart and knows that I desire a stable, good and united church, so I do speak what is already in my heart. That I will do everything in my power to protect your person and those who follow you as we reform what festers at the heart of our sacred church. I want our holy father to know that he is not just under the protection of Juan, but that the entire crown and kingdom of Castille is at his disposal. My people are devout and God-fearing and will answer should I ask them to service. I say this without thought of reward nor do I aim to influence the holy father. And am happy to repeat this oath in public when convenient.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope is moved but will not show it fully. He accepts with gravity and grace, speaking of mutual obligation rather than protection. He maintains the fiction that he is not desperate, yet his voice carries genuine warmth as he raises Juan from his knees.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rise, Your Majesty. God's providence has brought you to Rome in this hour. We accept your pledge as we hope you will accept ours—that the Church remembers those who serve her faithfully, and that your devotion shall not go unwitnessed before the throne of the Almighty.

roll.outcome: Dignified Reserve — The Pope is moved but will not show it fully. He accepts with gravity and grace, speaking of mutual obligation rather than protection. Maintains the fiction that he is not desperate.

encounters.recap: Juan kneels before Pope Eugenius and formally pledges the protection of his person and the full resources of Castile for Church reform, disclaiming any desire for reward or influence. The Pope, maintaining his dignity while clearly moved, accepts the pledge with gravity and speaks of mutual obligation, raising Juan with genuine warmth tempered by papal reserve.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius looks down at the kneeling king for a long moment. Something moves behind his eyes—something that might be emotion, quickly mastered.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Rise, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice is steady. Formal. The voice of the Vicar of Christ, not the exhausted man who wept in this chamber hours ago. He waits until Juan stands, then continues. His hands are clasped before him, his posture straight. The papal dignity reassembled like armor.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We accept your pledge. And We thank you for it. But let Us be clear about what this is. You speak of protection—of Castile at Our disposal. These are generous words. Perhaps too generous. The Pope of Rome does not require a protector. The Church has stood for fourteen centuries. She will stand fourteen more, God willing, with or without Castilian swords.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the window, his white robes catching the last of the evening light.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: What We accept is not protection. What We accept is alliance. Partnership in a holy work. You have pledged yourself to the reform of the Church. Very well. We pledge Ourselves to the same cause. We stand together—not as protector and protected, but as servants of the same Master.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice softens slightly—but only slightly.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: If you repeat this oath publicly, let it be framed thus. Not that Castile shields a weak Pope, but that Christian princes stand with the Holy Father against corruption. The distinction matters. To Our enemies. To Basel. To history.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to stand before Juan.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We believe your heart is true, Juan of Castile. We have seen enough false men to recognize a real one. But belief is not the same as certainty. Certainty must be earned. By both of us. In the days ahead.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He extends his hand—the Fisherman's Ring glinting in the candlelight.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Now. You spoke of signing the Basel decrees. Let us continue.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy father; should we include a letter or declaration with these decrees explaining how we recognize these reforms and adopt them on their own merit, not because the council decreed it? Underscore the principle of parallel legislation?

roll.outcome: Dignified Reserve — The Pope is moved but will not show it fully. He accepts with gravity and grace, speaking of mutual obligation rather than protection. Maintains the fiction that he is not desperate.

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius responds to Juan's pledge with carefully controlled dignity, reframing the offer from protection to alliance between equals. While moved by Juan's sincerity, the Pope maintains papal authority and warns that trust must be earned through future actions.

exchanges.text: He extends his hand—the Fisherman's Ring glinting in the candlelight.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Now. You spoke of signing the Basel decrees. Let us continue.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy father; should we include a letter or declaration with these decrees explaining how we recognize these reforms and adopt them on their own merit, not because the council decreed it? Underscore the principle of parallel legislation?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius pauses, his hand hovering over the Basel documents spread across the desk.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Yes. A declaration would be... prudent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli steps forward, his earlier hesitation replaced by something sharper. Professional. This is his territory.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If I may, Holy Father. The danger is that Basel will claim Your Holiness has submitted to conciliar authority. Cardinal d'Allemand will write to every court in Europe: 'The Pope signs what we decree. The Council rules.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the desk, eyes scanning the documents.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But if the papal signature is accompanied by a declaration—motu proprio, by Your Holiness's own initiative—stating that these reforms are adopted independently, on their own merit, as an exercise of papal authority... Then the narrative changes. The Pope and Council happen to agree. Neither submits to the other.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The same reform, two authorities, each claiming credit.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Precisely. And when France complains about the reforms—and they will complain, Holy Father, when annates are reduced and pluralism curtailed—they must choose. Do they appeal to Basel, who passed these decrees? Or to Rome, who enacted them independently? Either way, they acknowledge someone's authority to reform.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty proposed this framework at Como, yes? The declaration should reference that. Not as submission to imperial mediation, but as evidence that this principle has been discussed, considered, agreed upon by multiple parties.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Carefully, Tommaso. We will not have it seem that Emperor Sigismund dictates Our policy any more than Basel does.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Of course, Holy Father. A passing reference only. The emphasis remains on papal initiative. Shall I draft something now? It need not be long. A preamble to accompany the signatures. We could have it ready within the hour.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Will a preamble being different from the Basel ones have legal ramifications? Will we create in effect two different legislations if we change the preamble?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's eyebrows rise slightly. A flicker of something—respect, perhaps—crosses his face.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: A perceptive question, Your Majesty. In canon law, a decree consists of several parts. The intitulatio—who issues it. The arenga—the preamble explaining why. The dispositio—the actual legal content, the operative clauses. And the sanctio—the penalties for violation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His finger traces down the document.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: What binds is the dispositio. The operative text. 'No cleric shall hold more than one benefice with cure of souls.' 'Annates shall be reduced to one quarter of the first year's revenue.' These are the rules. These are what parish priests and bishops must obey.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The preamble—the arenga—explains the rationale. Why the reform is needed. Under whose authority it proceeds. This is important for legitimacy, for history, for understanding intent. But it does not change what the law requires.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If His Holiness signs the Basel decrees with an accompanying declaration stating that he adopts these reforms motu proprio, on their own merit, as an independent exercise of papal authority—the operative content remains identical. The same rules. The same penalties. A priest in Lyon or Cologne faces the same requirements regardless of whether he believes the authority flows from Basel or Rome.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But the question of authority remains unresolved.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Deliberately so, Holy Father. That is the elegance of parallel legislation. Both authorities claim credit. Neither submits. The law is unified. The theory remains contested.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: There is one complication. If disputes arise—if a bishop challenges his removal for pluralism, for example—he might argue that the two sources of authority create ambiguity. 'Which version governs? Basel's or Rome's?' But the answer is simple: both. The content is identical. He violates both simultaneously. He cannot escape by playing one against the other. Does this address Your Majesty's concern?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Draft an accompanying letter with the decrees then. The world should know why the pope signed these decrees.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes parallel legislation to allow the Pope to sign Basel's reform decrees while asserting independent papal authority. Parentucelli explains the legal framework, showing how identical operative content can have different preambles without creating conflicting laws. They agree to draft a papal declaration to accompany the signature, framing the reforms as papal initiative rather than submission to conciliar authority.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
