exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli nods, already moving toward the writing desk. His earlier hesitation has vanished entirely—this is his element, the crafting of documents that will be read for centuries.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I shall draft it now. His Holiness can review and amend as needed. The tone must be... delicate. We acknowledge the reforms without acknowledging Basel's authority to decree them. We praise the substance without praising the source.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins to write, speaking aloud as he does—half to himself, half to his audience.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Eugenius, Episcopus, Servus Servorum Dei... the standard opening. Then— We speak of the Church's constant need for reform. Ecclesia semper reformanda. This is uncontroversial. Everyone agrees the Church needs reform. The question is merely who has authority to do it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His quill scratches steadily.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: We note that certain proposals for reform have emerged from various quarters of Christendom. We do not name Basel specifically—or rather, we name them among others. The Council. The Emperor. Christian princes. All have called for reform. We have listened.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But listening is not submitting.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Exactly, Holy Father. We state that we have examined these proposals and found them consonant with ancient canon law and the good of souls. We adopt them not because any council commands, but because they are right. Because papal authority exists precisely to enact such reforms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He writes in silence for several minutes. The only sound is the scratch of quill on parchment and the guttering of candles. Finally, he sets down the quill and reads the complete draft aloud, from the formal opening through the operative clauses to the powerful closing about the shepherd and the wolf.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Any remarks father? I think it explains it quite well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius studies the draft in silence, his lips moving slightly as he reads certain phrases again. His fingers trace the line about the shepherd and the wolf.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The shepherd does not ask which sheep first saw the wolf. Yes. That is... good. One small addition. Where you write 'not at the command of any council or prince'—add 'but in harmony with the ancient tradition of the Church.' It softens the defiance slightly. We are not merely rejecting Basel's authority; we are affirming something older and greater than either of us.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And here— 'If others have spoken these same truths, We rejoice in the unity of Christian conscience.' Change 'rejoice' to 'acknowledge.' Rejoicing suggests we are grateful to Basel for showing us the way. We are not grateful. We are... concurrent.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Otherwise, it serves. Tommaso, you have a gift for this work. We chose well. Let it be written fair. We sign tonight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli writes the fair copy with the care of a man who knows this document will be studied for centuries. When he finishes, he presents it to Eugenius. The Pope reads it once more, then takes up the quill and signs with a flourish. The seal follows—the Fisherman's Ring pressed into warm wax.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It is done. Rome has spoken on reform. Whatever Basel says now, they cannot claim we waited for their permission. Three reforms that will make Us enemies throughout Christendom. Cardinals who keep concubines. Bishops who hold six benefices. Officials who grow fat on annates. They will not thank Us for this night's work.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: They will hate us, Holy Father. But they will obey. The law is clear. The authority is unambiguous. And the enforcement will be real.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Two documents signed. The commission. The declaration. Now comes the greater work. The Camera reform itself. The decree that will truly shake the pillars. But first—tell Us again, Your Majesty. This proposal of yours. The clean ledger. All existing obligations transferred to the College of Cardinals. Walk Us through it once more, that Tommaso may begin to see its shape.

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius IV signs an apostolic declaration asserting independent papal authority over church reforms. The carefully crafted document adopts the Basel reform decrees on pluralism, concubinage, and annates while explicitly rejecting Basel's authority to command papal action. The declaration presents the Pope as acting from his own initiative and ancient tradition rather than council mandate.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Two documents signed. The commission. The declaration. Now comes the greater work. The Camera reform itself. The decree that will truly shake the pillars. But first—tell Us again, Your Majesty. This proposal of yours. The clean ledger. All existing obligations transferred to the College of Cardinals. Walk Us through it once more, that Tommaso may begin to see its shape.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Camera's obligations fall into several categories, Your Majesty. Let me describe what I know—and what I suspect.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: First, the internal obligations. Salaries. The Camera employs perhaps sixty clerks, notaries, scriptores, and minor officials. These men must be paid. Most receive modest stipends—a few florins monthly. But the senior positions... The vice-camerlengos, the auditors, the depositarii—these men have negotiated arrangements over decades.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I would estimate—and this is estimate only, Your Majesty, I have not seen the actual ledgers—that internal salaries and stipends consume perhaps eight to twelve thousand florins annually. But the true cost is hidden in the percentages. A collector who keeps one-fifth of what he gathers does not appear as an expense. He simply... reduces revenue.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have suspected as much. Continue.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Second, the external obligations. And here—here is where the rot runs deepest. The Camera has borrowed. Heavily. For decades. Your Holiness's predecessors faced wars, schisms, councils. Martin V had to rebuild Rome from nothing after the Avignon chaos. All of this required money the Camera did not have.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: From whom?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Italian banks. The Medici, primarily—they have been papal bankers for years now. Before them, the Alberti. The Spini. Others. These families do not lend from charity. They lend at interest—disguised as fees and service charges to avoid the usury prohibition, but interest nonetheless.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I do not know the total debt. No one outside the Camera itself knows, and I suspect even those inside do not have a clear accounting. But I have heard figures whispered. Forty thousand florins to the Medici alone. Perhaps another twenty thousand scattered among smaller lenders. And these debts carry obligations—not merely repayment, but preferences.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Sixty thousand florins in debt?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: At minimum, Holy Father. Possibly more. And the debt is not static. Interest accumulates. When payments are missed, the principal grows. The Camera borrows to pay interest on previous borrowing. It is—a wheel that turns ever faster.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: This is why the clean ledger approach is both elegant and dangerous, Your Majesty. If we declare existing obligations null and void, we are declaring that the Church will not honor its debts. The Medici will not accept this quietly.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What leverage?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: They hold papal correspondence. Records of transactions. Evidence of... arrangements... that would be embarrassing if made public. They know which cardinals have borrowed personally, using Church revenues as collateral. They know which benefices have been promised to multiple parties. And they have friends. In Basel. In Florence. In every court in Europe.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No, the church will honour obligations. I have deposited an enormous treasury into the camera not just a year ago. The amount would have covered any debt many times over if it is indeed around 60,000 florins. I think one of the first tasks of Tommaso is to review the extent of what the treasury actually is and what external obligations do exist. If need be, I can let Castille offer donation to cover any debt the camera cannot pay. Now, tell me more about a cardinal borrowing against income streams of the church. Is this not illegal?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Illegal. In the strictest sense, yes. Church property belongs to the Church. A benefice holder has use of its revenues during his tenure—the usufruct—but he does not own them. He cannot sell them. He cannot, in theory, pledge them as collateral. But theory and practice diverge, Your Majesty. Widely.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Consider a cardinal who holds three benefices generating—let us say—four thousand florins annually. He wishes to build a palazzo. Or to purchase a library. Or to maintain a household of forty servants and a stable of fine horses. He goes to a banker. The banker knows his income. The banker offers a loan—ten thousand florins, perhaps.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And the collateral?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Nothing so crude as a signed pledge against Church revenues. That would be evidence. Instead... An understanding. The cardinal's revenues flow through the banker's house—as they must, for transfers across borders require banking networks. The banker simply... retains a portion. Each quarter, each year. To service the debt.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This is usury.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It is usury, simony, and theft from the Church, all wrapped in enough legal fiction to maintain deniability. The interest is called a service fee. The pledge is called an informal arrangement. The retention of revenues is called administrative convenience. No document exists that explicitly violates canon law. Yet the effect is the same.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How widespread is this?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I cannot say with certainty. I have watched from the outside, Holy Father. I have heard conversations not meant for my ears. I have noted which cardinals live far beyond the official revenues of their benefices. But I have no proof. Not yet. The proof is in the Camera's records—and in the bankers' private ledgers, which we will never see.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: When I begin my work, Your Majesty, I will look for the threads. Revenues that should arrive but do not. Payments made to accounts that cannot be traced. Benefices whose income has been assigned to third parties through obscure instruments. If the rot is as deep as I suspect, the evidence will be there. Hidden, but there.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me more about the whole church and what revenue comes to the camera and what revenue stays locally. How much of the money stream does the camera control?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli provides detailed analysis of Camera Apostolica's financial obligations, revealing systemic corruption including 60,000+ florins in debt to Italian banks, illegal cardinal borrowing against Church revenues, and embedded banking influence. Juan commits to honoring debts using Castilian treasury and orders comprehensive audit.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: When I begin my work, Your Majesty, I will look for the threads. Revenues that should arrive but do not. Payments made to accounts that cannot be traced. Benefices whose income has been assigned to third parties through obscure instruments. If the rot is as deep as I suspect, the evidence will be there. Hidden, but there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His voice hardens.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: And if I find cardinals who have pledged Church property to foreign bankers for personal gain—that, Your Majesty, is illegal. Not merely improper. Not merely unseemly. It is theft from the faithful and betrayal of sacred office.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances at Eugenius.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: What happens to such men, if we find them, is a question for His Holiness. But finding them... Finding them will be my pleasure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's eyes sharpen. This is not gossip or inference—this is the architecture of Church finance, the system he has studied for two decades.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Church of Christ generates enormous wealth, Your Majesty. Tithes from every parish. Rents from vast landholdings. Fees for sacraments, burials, masses for the dead. Offerings from the faithful. If one could sum it all—every coin that passes through ecclesiastical hands from Ireland to Hungary, from Sicily to Sweden—Millions of florins. Perhaps tens of millions. No one knows the true figure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins to pace, his scholar's mind organizing the information.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: But the Camera sees only a fraction of this. A small fraction. Perhaps one part in twenty. Perhaps less.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops, turning to face them.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let me explain the structure. Think of the Church as a great tree. The roots are the parishes—tens of thousands of them across Christendom. Each parish collects tithes from its people. One-tenth of the harvest, the traditional levy. This alone generates vast sums.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Most stays local. The parish priest takes his living—modest, usually. The remainder rises to the bishop. The bishop takes his share for the cathedral chapter, the diocesan administration, his own household. What remains after that... In theory, a portion should flow upward still. In practice, it rarely does. The bishops guard their revenues jealously.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He resumes pacing.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: So the Camera cannot tax the tithes directly. What Rome receives comes through other channels.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins counting on his fingers.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: First: Annates. When a bishop or abbot is appointed to a new benefice, he owes Rome a portion of the first year's income. Historically, this was the full first year—hence the name, from annus. The Basel reform reduces this to one-quarter. This has been our largest reliable revenue. Perhaps forty to fifty thousand florins annually, depending on how many appointments occur.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Second: Servitia communia and servitia minuta. Fees paid by bishops and abbots upon confirmation of their appointment. These are in addition to annates—a separate extraction. Perhaps fifteen to twenty thousand florins.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Third: The pallium fees. Every archbishop must receive the pallium from Rome—the woolen band that symbolizes his authority. The fee for this varies by the wealth of the see. A great archbishopric like Mainz or Canterbury might pay thousands of florins. Smaller ones, hundreds. Combined, perhaps ten thousand florins annually.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Fourth: Dispensations. This is where the corruption festers most visibly. A man wishes to marry his cousin. He needs a dispensation. A priest wishes to hold two benefices simultaneously—pluralism. He needs a dispensation. A bishop wishes to ordain a man below the canonical age. Dispensation. Every deviation from canon law requires Roman permission, and Roman permission requires payment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops before Juan.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The fee schedules are Byzantine in their complexity. A dispensation for marriage within the fourth degree of consanguinity costs one amount. The third degree, more. The second degree, more still. Legitimization of children born to clergy, more. Permission to eat meat during Lent for health reasons, less—but still something. There is a fee for everything. And the Camera collects.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Impossible to say with precision. The dispensations vary wildly year to year. Perhaps twenty thousand florins. Perhaps forty. It depends on how many bishops die, how many nobles wish to marry cousins, how many priests wish to accumulate benefices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He continues, his voice taking on a rhythmic quality—a lecturer in his element.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Fifth: Judicial fees. Any case may be appealed to Rome. Indeed, many cases must be appealed to Rome—disputes over benefices, accusations against clergy, marriage annulments. Each stage of the process requires payment. Filing fees. Advocate fees. Scribal fees. Sealing fees. A complex case might generate hundreds of florins before judgment is rendered.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Sixth: Vacant benefices. When a benefice holder dies, the revenues during the vacancy flow to Rome—in theory. In practice, the local bishop often claims them first, and Rome receives only what it can enforce. Perhaps five thousand florins, perhaps less.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Seventh: Peter's Pence. The ancient tribute from England and certain other kingdoms. Small compared to the others—a few thousand florins—but symbolically important.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Eighth: Crusade levies. Special taxes imposed for holy war. These require cooperation from secular rulers and church councils. Sporadic. Unpredictable. Sometimes substantial—as Your Majesty's own contribution demonstrated. Sometimes nothing for years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops, spreading his hands.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Sum it all together, Your Majesty. In a typical year—if such a thing exists—the Camera might expect one hundred to one hundred fifty thousand florins. In a good year, with many appointments and few conflicts, perhaps more. In a bad year, with schism and war disrupting collections... Far less.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And We have not seen a good year since taking the throne.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: No, Holy Father. The schism with Basel has disrupted collections across Germany and France. Bishops appointed by the Council do not pay annates to Rome. Dispensation seekers go to Basel instead. The French clergy cite Gallican liberties to withhold payments. The revenue that should flow to Rome... diverts.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: This is why the Camera has borrowed so heavily. The expected revenue no longer arrives. But the expenses continue. The papal household. The Curia. The guards. The building projects begun by previous popes. The interest on previous debts. The Camera spends one hundred thousand florins regardless of whether it receives one hundred thousand florins.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pauses.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: And this brings us to your question, Your Majesty. How much does the Camera control? The answer is: far less than it once did, and far less than it needs. The great tree of Church wealth grows vast, but the roots keep most of the water. Rome receives only what trickles up through cracks in the system—annates, fees, dispensations. And even that trickle is drying up.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at the signed reforms on the desk.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The decrees we have just signed will reduce that trickle further. Annates cut by three-quarters. Pluralism restricted, which means fewer dispensation fees. These are good reforms—necessary reforms—but they will cost the Camera dearly. If we also cancel existing obligations and debts, we must understand what remains. The answer may be: almost nothing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should not cancel existing obligations just yet. First, let's look at the expenses side of the camera. You told me that the salaries of the camera scribes are a few thousand a year. Surely, the camera has other expenses?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli provides a comprehensive analysis of Church finances, detailing how papal revenues total only 100-150,000 florins annually from various fees and taxes, while the vast majority of Church wealth stays at local levels. He warns that recent reforms will further reduce papal income while expenses remain constant.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The expenses. Yes. This is where the money goes, and it reveals much about why the Camera is always empty. The clerical salaries I mentioned—eight to twelve thousand florins—are actually among the more defensible expenses. Scribes must be paid. Notaries must be paid. The work of the Church requires administration.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But beyond salaries, the expenses multiply. First: The Papal Household. His Holiness must be fed, clothed, housed, and attended. The apostolic palace requires servants—cooks, cleaners, stewards, grooms. The papal chapel requires chaplains, singers, musicians for ceremonies. There are physicians, confessors, secretaries for personal correspondence.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Holiness lives more simply than your predecessors. This is known. But even a modest papal household consumes fifteen to twenty thousand florins annually. A immodest household— Martin V spent nearly twice that. And he was considered restrained compared to the Avignon popes.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Second: The Sacred College. Cardinals receive subsidies from the Camera. Not all of them—those with wealthy benefices need nothing. But cardinals in curia—those residing in Rome, attending to Church business—receive allowances for housing, servants, and maintenance appropriate to their dignity.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It varies by cardinal and by what they can negotiate. Some receive a few hundred florins. Others, thousands. In total? Perhaps twenty to thirty thousand florins annually flows to the College in direct subsidies. And this does not count the indirect benefits—the benefices reserved for their nominees, the dispensation fees they share, the appointments they influence.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Visconti threat has cost Us dearly these past years.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Yes, Holy Father. Military expenses in a troubled year might reach thirty or forty thousand florins. Perhaps more.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Sum it all, Your Majesty. In a typical year, the Camera must spend—at minimum—one hundred thousand florins. Salaries: ten thousand. Papal household: twenty thousand. Cardinals' subsidies: twenty-five thousand. Curial operations: fifteen thousand. Diplomacy: fifteen thousand. Military: ten thousand in peacetime, far more in war. Building: ten thousand for maintenance alone. Charity: five thousand. Debt service: six thousand.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: That is one hundred sixteen thousand florins, and I have been conservative in every estimate. The Camera receives perhaps one hundred thousand florins in a good year. It spends one hundred sixteen thousand in a quiet year. The deficit is covered by borrowing—which increases debt service—which increases the deficit. This is why the Camera is always empty. This is why your crusade treasury vanished.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: And the reforms we have just signed will reduce revenue further, while leaving expenses unchanged. Unless we also reform the expenses.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should both address income and expense. Tommaso, I expect you can reform the salaries or expenses cardinals receive from the camera to a more modest and acceptable level? This is what I would mean by starting with a clean slate. To live not in poverty but to maintain papal dignity and to perform the tasks expected of it, a certain salary is appropriate.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Or maybe...the Basel decree separates the camera from the college of cardinals. Are the cardinals not expected now to receive their income and salary from this college? What part of the expenses just listed should be directed to this college and what expenses stay with the camera?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli provides a comprehensive breakdown of Camera expenses totaling 116,000 florins annually against revenues of only 100,000 florins. Major expense categories include papal household (20,000), cardinal subsidies (25,000), military costs (10,000+), and debt service (6,000). Juan proposes reforming cardinal expenses and questions whether the Basel decree's separation of Camera and College of Cardinals might redistribute some costs.

I have not included extraordinary expenses—a council, a jubilee, a war, a major building project. I have not included the informal expenses that never appear in ledgers—the gifts to secure loyalty, the bribes to prevent opposition, the quiet payments that keep the machinery turning.

With you in full control of Camera expenses, we can trim the fat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli goes still. His eyes unfocus slightly—the look of a scholar whose mind has seized upon a problem.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Basel decree on annates. Half to the Camera, half to the metropolitan—which in practice means the cardinals controlling those provinces... Your Majesty asks the essential question. If we divide the income, should we not also divide the expenses?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the desk, pulling the annates decree closer, scanning its text though he likely knows it from memory.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Basel fathers did not address this. They thought only of reducing Rome's extraction from the provinces. They did not consider—or did not care—how Rome would then fund itself. Perhaps they hoped we would simply wither.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sets down the document and begins to pace, his movements quicker now.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But let us think through the logic. The Camera, as currently constituted, funds everything. Papal household. Cardinals' subsidies. Curial offices. Diplomacy. Military. Building. Charity. All from one purse, with no clear accounting of which revenues support which functions.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If we accept the Basel framework—truly accept it, not merely sign it—then we must ask: what is the Camera for? What is its essential function? The Camera exists to fund the papacy. The Holy Father. The administration that serves him directly. The household. The guards. The diplomatic missions he sends. The buildings he maintains. The charity he dispenses in Christ's name. These are papal expenses. They should come from papal revenue—the Camera's half of the annates, plus whatever other fees remain.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But the cardinals? The Sacred College? They are not the Pope's servants. They are—in theory—his advisors, his electors, his partners in governance. Why should the Pope fund their palazzos? Why should papal revenue pay for their households, their retinues, their libraries and banquets?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If the College of Cardinals receives half the annates under Basel's decree, then let the College fund itself from that half. Let them determine among themselves how to divide it. Let them decide which of their number deserves a subsidy and which can live from his benefices alone.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: They will not accept this willingly.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: No, Holy Father. They will not. But consider the alternative they face. If they refuse—if they demand the Camera continue funding their subsidies—then they are admitting they cannot govern themselves. They are admitting they need papal charity. And they must make this admission publicly, after Basel has just given them an independent revenue stream.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The beauty of this approach, Your Majesty, is that it uses Basel's own decree against the cardinals who supported it. They wanted independence from papal control? Very well—they shall have it. Independence means funding themselves.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the desk, his mind clearly racing.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let me think through the division. Expenses that remain with the Camera—the papal expenses: Clerical salaries for Camera staff—yes, perhaps eight thousand florins. Papal household—twenty thousand. Papal guard—eight thousand. Diplomatic missions sent in the Pope's name—fifteen thousand. Building maintenance for papal properties—ten thousand. Charitable works—five thousand. Debt service on existing obligations—six thousand, until debts are cleared. Perhaps seventy thousand florins in core papal expenses. Possibly less if we trim carefully.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Cardinals' subsidies—twenty-five thousand florins, gone from the Camera entirely. Let them fund themselves. And certain curial offices might also shift. The Rota Romana hears appeals that benefit the whole Church, not just the Pope. The Penitentiary serves all Catholics. Perhaps some portion of curial expenses—say five to ten thousand florins—should come from the College's share.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If we execute this cleanly, the Camera's expenses fall from over one hundred thousand florins to perhaps seventy thousand. Meanwhile, the College inherits responsibility for thirty to forty thousand in expenses—from a revenue stream that might generate only twenty to thirty thousand florins, depending on appointments. They will have to economize, Holy Father. They will have to choose between subsidizing Cardinal Colonna's palazzo and funding the Rota's operations. They will have to govern rather than merely extract.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Is this what Your Majesty envisions? The Camera stripped to essential papal functions, the College made responsible for itself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Is this not the spirit of what the Basel reforms envisioned as well?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli provides a detailed breakdown of Camera expenses (116,000 florins annually vs 100,000 in revenue) and proposes restructuring papal finances by using the Basel decree to force the College of Cardinals to fund itself from their share of annates, reducing Camera expenses to essential papal functions of around 70,000 florins.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli pauses. A strange expression crosses his face—something between admiration and dark amusement.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The spirit of Basel. Yes. And no. And that is what makes this so elegant.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the window, gathering his thoughts.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Council fathers at Basel sought to decentralize Church governance. To break Rome's monopoly on revenue and power. To give metropolitans and provinces greater authority over their own affairs. The annates decree does precisely this—half the revenue stays closer to where it originates, under the metropolitan's control rather than the Camera's. But the Council fathers made an assumption. They assumed that reducing papal revenue would weaken papal power. They assumed the Pope would be forced to come begging to the Council for funds, making him dependent on conciliar goodwill. What they did not consider is that a Pope might accept reduced revenue and reduce expenses accordingly. They did not imagine that Rome might say: 'Very well. We shall live within our means. And so shall the cardinals.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins pacing again, his voice taking on the cadence of a lecturer.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Basel's reformers hate two things above all: papal tyranny and curial corruption. They see both as intertwined—the Pope extracts money from Christendom to fund a bloated, venal court that serves no one but itself. What we propose addresses both concerns. The Camera's extractions are reduced—Basel's explicit goal. But the curial bloat is also reduced—the cardinals must fund themselves from their own share rather than feeding at the papal trough. The Pope becomes leaner, more focused, more... apostolic. Less a Renaissance prince and more a shepherd.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His eyes meet Juan's.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If Basel's spirit is genuine reform of Church governance, then yes—this fulfills that spirit more completely than Basel itself imagined. We are not merely reducing revenue. We are restructuring responsibility. But I must be honest, Your Majesty. The men at Basel—Cardinal d'Allemand, the French faction—they do not want a reformed papacy. They want a subordinate papacy. A Pope who must ask the Council's permission before acting. They will not celebrate this interpretation. They will call it trickery, evasion, a perversion of their intent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He shrugs.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let them. The decree says what it says. Half to the Camera, half to the metropolitans and cardinals. It does not say the Camera must continue funding cardinals' subsidies from its diminished share. It does not say the Pope must beggar himself while cardinals live in splendor. When this is announced—when the full implications become clear—Basel will face a choice. Do they denounce reforms they themselves decreed? Do they demand the Pope increase spending on cardinals? Do they argue that Church revenues should fund palazzos rather than charity?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A cold satisfaction enters his voice.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Every argument they make will expose them. They claimed to want reform. We are giving them reform—more reform than they ever intended. If they object, they reveal that their true goal was never reform at all. It was merely power. So yes, Your Majesty. This is the spirit of Basel. Distilled. Purified. Turned back upon those who thought themselves clever. The Council wanted to teach Rome a lesson about living within its means. We shall be excellent students.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Would the bishops and cardinals. The offices who will have their revenues reduced be able to perform their function properly? Do we not unduly reduce their income?

encounters.recap: Parentucelli presents his economic reform proposal that would shift expenses from the papal Camera to the College of Cardinals while reducing overall spending. He argues this fulfills Basel's reform spirit better than the Council intended, forcing cardinals to economize while making the papacy leaner and more apostolic. Juan questions whether reduced revenues would impair ecclesiastical functions.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Would the bishops and cardinals. The offices who will have their revenues reduced be able to perform their function properly? Do we not unduly reduce their income?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: A fair question, Your Majesty. And one I should address honestly. Not all cardinals are equal. Not all bishops are wealthy. The Sacred College contains men of vastly different circumstances.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Consider Cardinal Colonna. His family has held lands around Rome for centuries. His personal income from family estates alone—before any benefice, before any curial position—exceeds what most bishops see in a decade. If the Camera ceased his subsidy tomorrow, he would not miss a single meal. His palazzo would remain full of servants. His stables would remain full of horses.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But then consider Cardinal Albergati. A Carthusian monk who rose through sanctity and scholarship. He has no family wealth. His benefices are modest. He lives simply because he believes in simplicity—but also because he has no choice. Without some support, he could not maintain even a minimal household. He could not travel to councils. He could not perform the functions expected of a cardinal.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: If we strip away all subsidies indiscriminately, we punish the Albergatis to spite the Colonnas. We make the Sacred College a preserve of the wealthy—only men with family fortunes or rich benefices could afford to serve. The poor scholar, the holy monk, the bishop from a minor see—these men would be excluded.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The same applies to bishops. The Archbishop of Toledo commands revenues that would make some princes envious. Reducing his annates by three-quarters still leaves him wealthy beyond measure. But the Bishop of some mountain diocese in Savoy? A see with thirty parishes and peasants who pay tithes in goats and cheese? That man struggles to maintain a cathedral chapter. Further reduction might genuinely impair his function.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: So the reform must distinguish. Between those who have much and those who have little.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Yes, Holy Father. The principle of reform is sound—the Camera should not fund luxury for those who need no help. But the application must be... discerning.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Perhaps the solution is this: the College of Cardinals receives its half of the annates as a common fund. From this fund, the College must pay for shared expenses—the Rota, the Penitentiary, whatever curial functions we assign to them. What remains after these obligations is divided among the cardinals themselves. But divided how? Not equally—that would give Cardinal Colonna the same subsidy as Cardinal Albergati, which serves no purpose. Instead, divided according to need. Cardinals with wealthy benefices or family fortunes receive nothing. Cardinals with modest means receive support sufficient to perform their functions with dignity—not luxury, but dignity.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: This forces the College to govern itself. To make decisions. To look their brother cardinals in the eye and say: 'You have enough. You need nothing from the common purse.' Or: 'You have little. We shall support you.' It makes them accountable to each other rather than simply drawing from an endless papal fountain.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The same principle could apply to bishops, through their metropolitans. The metropolitan receives the provincial share of annates. He distributes support to suffragan bishops according to need—wealthy sees receive nothing, poor sees receive help. The metropolitan becomes responsible for his province's welfare, not merely its extraction.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Will some bishops and cardinals see their income reduced? Yes. Substantially. But these will be the men who least need it—those with multiple benefices, family wealth, comfortable arrangements. Will the truly poor be protected? They can be, if the system is designed properly.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The question is whether the College and the metropolitans can be trusted to distribute fairly. History suggests... caution. The wealthy look after the wealthy. The powerful protect the powerful. But that is where enforcement matters. If the Camera reform decree includes provisions requiring transparent accounting from the College—if Albergati can see exactly how much Colonna receives and demand justification—then the pressure for fairness increases. Sunlight, as we discussed. Let them make their decisions, but make them publicly.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Does this address Your Majesty's concern? The reform need not impoverish those who are already poor. It need only cease enriching those who are already rich.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. This sounds great. I am thinking about if we should include corruption investigations into the reforms as well. If the rot is indeed as deep as we fear, we may put a great part of the church against the wall and we reduce the chance of this reform succeeding. Maybe curb the largest excess?

encounters.recap: Juan raises concerns about whether reducing church revenues will harm poor bishops and cardinals. Parentucelli proposes a nuanced reform system that protects clergy with modest means while cutting subsidies to wealthy prelates through needs-based distribution and transparent accounting. Juan expresses satisfaction but wonders about adding corruption investigations to the reforms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli is silent for a long moment. His jaw works. Something wars behind his eyes.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... Your Majesty is wise to consider this carefully. I spoke earlier of justice. Of finding the men who pledged Church property to bankers. Of holding them accountable. Part of me still wants this. Twenty years of watching, Your Majesty. Twenty years of seeing good priests ground down while corrupt men prospered. The ledger in my heart cries out for balance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the window, his back partially turned. He turns back. His face is composed, but something burns beneath.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: But you are right. If we announce investigations alongside the reform—if cardinals wake tomorrow fearing not just reduced income but imprisonment, disgrace, ruin—they will unite against us. Every man with a secret becomes an enemy. Every family with something to hide becomes a faction seeking our destruction.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius stirs in his chair.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have thought on this as well. When We spoke of bringing down the hammer, We meant reform. Structural change. Not... Not trials. Not executions. Not dragging princes of the Church before tribunals. The Church has seen such purges before. They do not end well. Accusations breed counter-accusations. Factions form. Men who might have accepted reform peacefully instead fight to the death because they have nothing left to lose.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, moving slowly toward the window where Parentucelli stands.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The mathematics of fear, Holy Father. A man who loses income grumbles but adapts. A man who faces investigation panics. A man who faces ruin has no reason for restraint. If we focus the decree purely on structural reform—the clean ledger, the separation of Camera and College, the reduction of expenses—we give the corrupt a path forward. They lose privilege, yes. They lose the system that enriched them. But they keep their positions. Their dignity. Their freedom. Some will even prosper under the new system, if they adapt. A cardinal who learned to extract under the old ways might learn to economize under the new. We offer them... conversion. A chance to become what they should have been.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius turns from the window.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And if they refuse? If corruption continues despite reform?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli's expression hardens.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Then we address it then, Holy Father. Specifically. Individually. When the new system is established, when the Camera is reformed, when we have evidence gathered under proper authority—then a single corrupt cardinal can be pursued without threatening the whole College. The system will be strong enough to survive removing one bad actor. But now? Tonight? If we try to reform the institution and punish its abusers simultaneously, we attempt too much. We create too many enemies at once. We give them common cause.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at Juan, and something like pain crosses his face.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It galls me to say this, Your Majesty. After everything I have seen. After everything I have burned to see corrected. But you are right. We should focus the decree on reform. On the future. On building something clean. Let the guilty keep their ill-gotten gains. Let them sleep peacefully in beds bought with stolen coin. The price of their comfort is a reformed Church that will never again permit such theft. Perhaps that is justice enough.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He does not sound convinced. But he sounds resigned. Eugenius speaks quietly.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We could include language. Something that preserves the possibility without creating immediate threat. 'The Holy See reserves the right to examine past practices as circumstances warrant.' It promises nothing. It threatens nothing specific. But it reminds them that mercy today does not guarantee mercy forever. Would such language serve? A door left open, but not walked through?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should first set the church straight. Stop the bleeding. And if there are some festering and visible corruption still visible, so much so that it harms our reform, we come after them. But I also think that most offenders also should be given a new chance. I think many would say; we did as we did because everyone did it and we had to do it to get ahead. Some took more advantage than others sure, but we should let bygones be bygones. I think we should make it clear that we do not prosecute actions that were aligned with the old way and habits of conducting business, but will from now on no longer tolerate it. We should make all well-meaning cardinals and bishops into allies not enemies. Yes, we should put that centrally. We need allies not enemies. We should make it easy for those cardinals who want to better their ways to join us without fear of prosecution.

encounters.recap: Juan, Eugenius, and Parentucelli debate whether to include corruption investigations in their church reforms. Despite Parentucelli's desire for justice after twenty years of witnessing abuse, they agree to focus solely on structural reform rather than punishment, offering corrupt officials a path to redemption rather than creating enemies through fear of prosecution.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Would such language serve? A door left open, but not walked through?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
