I think we should make it clear that we do not prosecute actions that were aligned with the old way and habits of conducting business, but will from now on no longer tolerate it. We should make all well-meaning cardinals and bishops into allies not enemies.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, we should put that centrally. We need allies not enemies. We should make it easy for those cardinals who want to better their ways to join us without fear of prosecution.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence holds the room for a long moment. Parentucelli stands motionless by the window. His hands have clenched at his sides. When he finally speaks, his voice is quiet. Controlled. The voice of a man setting something down that he has carried for a very long time.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Allies. Not enemies. Yes. Yes, Your Majesty is... correct. If a cardinal looks at this reform and sees only threat—only loss, only danger—he will fight it. But if he looks and sees... a path forward. A way to become something better without first being destroyed for what he was...

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Church I have watched for twenty years was not built by monsters. It was built by ordinary men making ordinary compromises. 'Everyone does it.' 'This is how things are done.' 'I must play the game or be crushed by those who do.' These are the whispers that corrupt good men by degrees. If we declare that all who whispered these things are criminals, we declare most of the Church criminal. But if we declare that the whispers were wrong—that the game itself was wrong—and offer a new game with new rules... Then the man who compromised his conscience has a choice. He can cling to the old ways and be exposed as corrupt. Or he can embrace the new ways and be reformed. Redeemed, even. His past sins... not forgotten, but... covered over by present virtue.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: This is the Gospel, is it not? Repentance and new life. The prodigal son returns and is welcomed, not punished for his years of dissolution.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have spent three years as Pope treating Our cardinals as enemies to be managed. Factions to be balanced. Threats to be contained. Perhaps We created enemies by expecting enemies. Perhaps if We had offered trust... No. The corruption was real. The threat was real. But now—with reform, with structure, with clear expectations—perhaps We can offer what We could not before. A new beginning. For them as well as for the Camera. Tommaso. You have the gift of language. How would you frame this? An amnesty that does not excuse—that acknowledges wrong was done—but offers forgiveness to those who embrace the new way?

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: We might say something like this, Holy Father: 'We acknowledge that practices have taken root which, though long tolerated by custom, do not accord with the ancient discipline of the Church nor the Gospel of Christ. We do not seek to punish those who followed paths that circumstance and precedent seemed to permit. Rather, We call all servants of the Church to walk henceforth in newness of life, setting aside former ways as a man sets aside the garments of his youth.' 'Let no man fear prosecution for what was done under the old dispensation, provided he embraces in good faith the reforms herein decreed. The past is rendered to God's mercy. The future is committed to our common labor.'

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Something of this nature. It acknowledges wrongdoing without naming criminals. It offers amnesty without excusing sin. It frames reform as invitation rather than prosecution. And it leaves one door open. 'Provided he embraces in good faith.' Those who publicly accept reform but secretly continue the old corruption—they have rejected the amnesty by their own actions. They can be pursued later, individually, as violators of new law rather than practitioners of old custom.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The hand extended in peace. But the sword kept ready for those who spit upon the hand.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Just so, Holy Father. Your Majesty spoke of stopping the bleeding first. Of making well-meaning men into allies. This is wisdom I did not possess an hour ago. I was thinking of justice. You are thinking of victory. They are not the same thing. And tonight, victory matters more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Tommaso, there may still come a time to bring those to justice who have commited corruption so large that they fall even outside the customs and habits we have just described. When the waters have calmed, when the bleeding is stopped, then there is a time and place for your fury. If we all work and fight in the grace of our lord, we all will see the reformed church we want in our hearts.

encounters.recap: Juan advocates for pragmatic amnesty over prosecution in Church reform, arguing for transforming potential enemies into allies. Parentucelli struggles with abandoning his desire for justice but ultimately accepts Juan's strategic wisdom. They craft language for an amnesty that acknowledges wrongdoing without prosecuting past corruption, while preserving the option to pursue future violations. The Pope embraces this reconciliation approach as both Gospel-centered and politically wise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli turns to Juan. Something has shifted in his bearing. The burning fury has not vanished—it has been... banked. Controlled. Channeled.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty spoke of stopping the bleeding first. Of making well-meaning men into allies. This is wisdom I did not possess an hour ago. I was thinking of justice. You are thinking of victory. They are not the same thing. And tonight, victory matters more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Tommaso, there may still come a time to bring those to justice who have commited corruption so large that they fall even outside the customs and habits we have just described. When the waters have calmed, when the bleeding is stopped, then there is a time and place for your fury. If we all work and fight in the grace of our lord, we all will see the reformed church we want in our hearts.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli goes very still. For a long moment he does not speak. His eyes glisten in the candlelight—though whether from the flickering flames or something else is impossible to say. When he finally responds, his voice is rough. Barely above a whisper.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is... kind. To say so.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns away, moving toward the window. His hand rises briefly to his face—a gesture quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: I have carried this weight for a long time. Watching. Recording. Remembering. Telling myself that someday—someday—it would matter. That someone would want to know what I had seen. There were nights I thought myself a fool. A secretary with delusions. Who was I to judge princes of the Church? Who was I to catalogue their sins as if I were the recording angel? A physician's son from Sarzana. A man who tutored other men's children to pay for his education. Nobody.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back. His eyes are bright, but his face is composed.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: And now I stand in a room with the Pope and a king, and they speak of reform as if it might actually happen. They ask my counsel. They value my knowledge. I do not know what to do with this, Your Majesty. I have prepared myself for disappointment so long that hope feels... dangerous.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Hope is dangerous, Tommaso. It has wounded Us more times than We can count. But despair is worse. Despair is surrender. And We have not come this far to surrender now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli looks at the Pope—his Pope now, in a way that was not true an hour ago. Something passes between them.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: No, Holy Father. We have not.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He straightens, squaring his shoulders. When he speaks again, the scholar has returned—but underneath, something new. Something warmer.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Your Majesty spoke of a time for fury. I will hold to that promise. When the waters calm. When the bleeding stops. When the reformed Church stands strong enough to bear the weight of justice. On that day, I will remember every name. Every transaction. Every sin committed not from custom but from pure greed. But until that day, I will build. I will count coins and audit ledgers and trim expenses. I will be the most meticulous, most boring, most relentless administrator the Camera has ever seen. The corrupt will learn to fear me not because I threaten them, but because I notice them. Because nothing escapes the ledger. Because every florin must be accounted for.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at Juan.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: This is how I will serve, Your Majesty. Not with a sword. With a quill. With patience. With the certain knowledge that the day of reckoning is delayed, not cancelled.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bows—a formal gesture, but one that carries genuine feeling.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Thank you. For seeing what I might become. Not just what I have been.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The day of reckoning is not delayed or cancelled Tommaso. It is merely coming. Like all good things, they take time. Look what we are accomplishing today. Rome was not built in one day.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Back to the reform itself. What else do we need to define in the reform to adress the corruption in the camera?

encounters.recap: Tommaso Parentucelli undergoes a profound emotional transformation, shifting from burning fury to controlled purpose. He reveals his deep personal pain from years of witnessing corruption while feeling powerless, and finds hope in Juan's promise of future justice. The Pope and Juan acknowledge his pain and offer him a meaningful role in reform, leading to a new bond of trust and shared purpose between all three men.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Thank you. For seeing what I might become. Not just what I have been.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The day of reckoning is not delayed or cancelled Tommaso. It is merely coming. Like all good things, they take time. Look what we are accomplishing today. Rome was not built in one day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A surprised sound escapes Parentucelli—something that might, in other circumstances, be called a laugh. Eugenius's lips twitch.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Rome indeed, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves back to the desk, his manner shifting. The wounded idealist has retreated; the administrator has emerged. He begins arranging the documents already signed, creating space for notes. He picks up a quill, not to write but to gesture with—a lecturer's habit.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: What else. Yes. Let me think through the structure systematically. We have established the principle: separation of Camera and College, reduction of expenses, amnesty for past practices. But principles require mechanisms. The decree must answer practical questions, or it becomes merely aspirational.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: First: The existing officials. The Camera currently employs dozens of men—clerks, notaries, collectors, auditors. What happens to them? If we dismiss everyone, we lose institutional knowledge. But if we retain everyone, we keep the very men who built and benefited from the corrupt system. I would suggest a middle path. All current officials are suspended pending review—my review, under the commission His Holiness has signed.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Second: The banking relationships. The Medici. The other lenders. The decree should establish that all Camera revenues flow through accounts controlled solely by papal officials. No banker retains funds on the Camera's behalf. No banker deducts fees without explicit written authorization for each transaction.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: The Medici will not like this. They profit enormously from being papal bankers—not merely from interest, but from the prestige, the information, the ability to say 'we handle the Pope's money.'

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Third: Transparency and audit. The current Camera operates in darkness. The decree should mandate regular accountings. Quarterly, perhaps. Published ledgers showing all revenues received and all expenses paid. Sunlight. As we discussed. When everyone can see the numbers, lies become difficult.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Fourth: The collection system. Currently, annates and fees are collected by a web of agents, sub-collectors, and local representatives—each taking a percentage, each adding delays, each creating opportunities for... leakage. The decree should simplify this. Fewer intermediaries.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Fifth: Document retention. This is crucial, Your Majesty. The Camera's records are... scattered. The decree should mandate that all Camera documents—past and present—are property of the Holy See and must be surrendered to central archives.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Sixth: Future violations. The amnesty covers the past. But what of the future? The decree must establish clear penalties for officials who continue corrupt practices under the new system.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: First of all, The offer of Castille stands. Best to keep it out of the decree itself. I think we should look at how much is still in the treasury and how much debt is owed. Are there other forms of corruption that we can adress? Or have we captured most with this draft?

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Other forms. Yes. There are... layers to this, Your Majesty. What I have described addresses the Camera's operations—how money flows in and out. But there are practices that exist alongside the Camera. Adjacent to it. Feeding on the same system.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let me describe what else festers. Simony. The sale of sacred offices. A bishop dies. Three candidates seek his see. One is learned and holy but poor. One is mediocre but has a wealthy patron. One is utterly unqualified but offers ten thousand florins to the right cardinal. Which one receives the appointment?

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Expectancies. Promises of future benefices. This creates a market in futures. Men trade expectancies like merchants trade grain contracts. The benefice becomes property to be bought and sold before its current holder is even cold.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Coadjutors with right of succession. The coadjutor pays for the privilege. The old bishop receives a pension from his own see's revenues. When he dies, the coadjutor inherits smoothly—because he has already purchased the position. The bishopric has become, in effect, heritable property.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Pensions charged on benefices. This allows a man to hold a benefice in all but name while appearing to comply with rules against pluralism. 'I have resigned the bishopric of X,' he says. 'I hold only Y.' But the bishop of X sends him three thousand florins annually, and everyone knows the truth.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: Compositions. When a man is caught in violation—holding incompatible benefices, living in concubinage, neglecting his duties—the Camera offers a choice. Face canonical penalties or... pay a fine. We have made confession itself a revenue stream. The worse the sin, the higher the fee.

exchanges.speaker: parentucelli
exchanges.text: But simony itself? The quiet exchange of favors for appointments? That requires changing hearts, not systems. As long as men value wealth over holiness, they will find ways to buy what should be given by grace. We can make it harder. We can make it riskier. We cannot make it impossible.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This all sounds good. Especially declare that we will no longer participate in the practice of compositions will be giving a good signal. This is much more than just a decree. It is a signal that the church is turning a page.

encounters.recap: Parentucelli systematically outlines comprehensive reform mechanisms for the Camera's operations, covering personnel review, banking relationships, transparency requirements, collection systems, document retention, and penalties for future violations. He then catalogs additional forms of Church corruption including simony, expectancies, coadjutors, pensions, and compositions. Juan affirms Castile's financial support and emphasizes that ending compositions will signal the Church's new direction.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This all sounds good. Especially declare that we will no longer participate in the practice of compositions will be giving a good signal. Your commission gives you a lot of power to find the worst offenders. But I think this decree should first and foremost signal that from now on, the church is faring a new course. This is much more than just a decree. It is a signal that the church is turning a page. Holy father, what you are doing is incredible. To announce this decree will be a historic moment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Eugenius is silent for a long moment. He stands by the window, his white robes pale in the dying light. Outside, Rome stretches toward the horizon—the city that has been his prison and his burden for four years. The city that tomorrow will learn its Pope has found his spine. When he speaks, his voice is rough.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Historic. We have thought of Our pontificate in many terms, Your Majesty. Beleaguered. Threatened. Survival. We have not dared to think of it as... historic.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns from the window. His eyes are bright.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: When they elected Us—when the cardinals placed this burden upon Our shoulders—We believed We might accomplish great things. We had plans. Visions. The reform of the Church. The reunion with the Greeks. The defense of Christendom against the Turk. Three years. Three years of councils that defied Us. Cardinals who schemed against Us. Armies at Our gates. We fled Rome in a fisherman's boat, Your Majesty. Disguised. Hunted. The Vicar of Christ, rowing across the Tiber in the dark like a common fugitive.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops before the desk where the signed documents lie—the commission, the declaration, the Basel reforms with papal seal.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We learned to think small. To survive today. To postpone tomorrow. To call it wisdom when it was merely... fear. And now this. In a single afternoon. A king who speaks of church bells and farmers at Mass. A scholar who has waited twenty years for someone to ask what he knows. And a Pope who remembers—finally remembers—why he wanted this throne at all.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His hand reaches out, fingers brushing the parchment.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You say what We are doing is incredible. Perhaps. But We could not do it alone. We have not done it alone. This is not Our achievement. This is... communion. Three men, in a room, deciding to stop being afraid.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He draws himself up. Something of the papal dignity returns—but warmer now, less defensive.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tomorrow will be difficult. The cardinals will rage. Basel will denounce Us. The Colonna and Orsini will scheme. There will be moments when We doubt. When We wish We had remained silent, remained safe, remained the frightened Pope who asked nothing and risked nothing. When those moments come—and they will come—We will remember this night. This room. The King of Castile, kneeling to pledge his sword to a cause not his own. The scholar from Sarzana, setting aside his fury for the sake of victory. And a Pope who finally stopped running.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reaches out and grips Juan's arm—the same gesture from hours ago, when he first began to believe.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Thank you. Whatever comes tomorrow, thank you. For seeing what We might become. For refusing to let Us remain what We were.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He releases Juan's arm and turns to Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And you, Tommaso. Our Commissarius Extraordinarius. We suspect you will make Us uncomfortable many times in the months ahead. You will tell Us things We do not wish to hear. You will find rot We would prefer not to know about. You will be... relentless. Good. We have had enough men who tell Us what We wish to hear. We need men who tell Us the truth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at the window. The light has faded almost entirely now. Evening has come to Rome.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But first, before We draft the final decree— We should have candles. And perhaps more wine. The night is young, and We have a Church to reform. Let us continue.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rings the bell.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tommaso, can we now touch pen to parchment? Create a new document and put the decree in it.

encounters.recap: Juan praises the Pope's reform decree as historic, prompting Eugenius to reflect emotionally on his pontificate's struggles and failures. The Pope expresses profound gratitude to Juan and Parentucelli for helping him rediscover his courage and purpose, acknowledging this moment as transformative communion between three men deciding to stop being afraid. They prepare to draft the final reform decree.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Good. We have had enough men who tell Us what We wish to hear. We need men who tell Us the truth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at the window. The light has faded almost entirely now. Evening has come to Rome.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But first, before We draft the final decree—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the small bell on the side table.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We should have candles. And perhaps more wine. The night is young, and We have a Church to reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rings the bell.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Let us continue.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli nods, moving to the desk with purpose. He selects a fresh sheet of parchment, tests his quill, and pauses—gathering the threads of hours of conversation into a single coherent document.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Let me structure this clearly, Your Majesty. His Holiness can amend as I draft.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He begins to write, speaking aloud as his quill moves.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: We begin with the arenga—the preamble explaining why this decree is necessary. Then the dispositio—the operative clauses, organized by subject. Then the amnesty and protection clauses. Finally, the dating and signature.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks up.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: This will be lengthy. The most comprehensive reform of papal finance in... perhaps ever. But length serves a purpose here. Every clause we include is a door closed against future corruption. Every mechanism we specify is a tool for enforcement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bends to his work. The candles burn low as Parentucelli writes. His quill moves steadily, pausing only when Eugenius suggests a word change or Juan raises a question of clarity. The room fills with the scratch of pen on parchment, the occasional murmur of Latin phrases being tested aloud. Hours pass. When Parentucelli finally sets down his quill, his hand is cramped and ink-stained. But his eyes are bright with something that might be triumph.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: It is done.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He reads the complete document aloud—all twenty articles, from the separation of Camera and College through the amnesty provisions to the final anathema against those who would oppose the reform. His voice grows stronger as he proceeds, the scholar giving way to something else. A man who has found his purpose. When he finishes, silence holds the chamber. Eugenius rises slowly from his chair. He moves to the desk and looks down at the document—page after page of careful Latin, the most comprehensive reform of papal finance in the history of the Church.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Bulla Reformationis. The Bull of Reform.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks at Juan, then at Parentucelli.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Tomorrow, when We announce this—when the cardinals learn what We have done—everything changes. There is no path back from this document. No retreat. No compromise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He picks up the quill.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have spent four years surviving. Tonight, We begin to reign.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He signs. † Eugenius PP. IV. The seal follows—the Fisherman's Ring pressed into crimson wax for the final time tonight. When Eugenius lifts his hand, the impression of Saint Peter's nets marks this document as authentic, binding, irrevocable. He steps back.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It is done. God help Us all.

encounters.recap: Working late into the night, Parentucelli drafts the comprehensive Bull of Reform—twenty articles covering papal financial reform from Camera separation to amnesty provisions. After hours of careful composition, Pope Eugenius signs the document, officially enacting the most comprehensive reform of papal finance in Church history.

encounters.location: Rome, Vatican Palace to Palazzo di San Marco

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The seal follows—the Fisherman's Ring pressed into crimson wax for the final time tonight. When Eugenius lifts his hand, the impression of Saint Peter's nets marks this document as authentic, binding, irrevocable.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: It is done. God help Us all.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Parentucelli glances toward the window. Beyond the glass, Rome lies dark—no trace of twilight remains. The candles have burned down to stubs, wax pooling on the silver holders.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Late, Your Majesty. The bells of Saint Peter's rang Compline some time ago. I would guess... the tenth or eleventh hour of the night? Perhaps later.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The cardinals will be asleep in their palazzos. Dreaming of tomorrow's intrigues. They do not know that tomorrow's world will be nothing like today's. Your Majesty should rest. Your queen waits at the Palazzo di San Marco—she will be worried. And tomorrow... Tomorrow will require strength none of us possess tonight.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We keep these documents with the pope for now. Tomorrow, I will again march my crusaders to st peter's to attend mass. I have done so before. One hour before eugenius makes the decrees public, we instruct the vatican guard to secure the camera. Tommaso will be needed there to make sure no-one destroys documents and that the treasury itself is secured. Then we will see what happens. But we should also be open for others to display good faith and good intentions. We rest tonight, tomorrow we continue God's work.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: A sound plan. The crusaders at Mass provide... context. Protection that appears as piety rather than force. You have done this before. The cardinals will think it merely the Castilian king's excessive devotion. Until it is too late.

exchanges.speaker: tommaso_parentucelli
exchanges.text: Holy Father, I will be at the Camera doors at dawn. Before dawn, if you wish. I want to see the building before the officials arrive. To understand the layout. To know which rooms hold the records, which hold the treasury. I have waited twenty years for tomorrow. I find I am... impatient for it to arrive.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We do not have words adequate to this night. What you have given Us—what you have helped Us become—Go to your queen. Hold your daughter. Pray with your confessor. And return tomorrow ready to shake the pillars of Christendom. Until tomorrow, Juan of Castile. God keep you through the night.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before you move to the Camera Tommaso, we should place a few dozen men under your command. You will need to secure the building. We meet again tomorrow, two hours before the adress. Until then, sleep the heavenly peace.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Vatican corridors are empty at this hour. Juan's footsteps echo against ancient stone as a single papal guard leads him through darkened passages toward the entrance where his escort waits. Outside, the March night is cold. Rome spreads before him—a city of domes and towers, of palazzos and ruins, all silver-blue under a crescent moon. Somewhere in those darkened buildings, cardinals sleep in their silk sheets, unaware that the world they know is about to end.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Palazzo di San Marco is dark save for a single window on the upper floor. Lucia's window. Still lit, despite the hour. She is waiting. Juan finds her in the small sitting room adjoining their chambers, wrapped in a heavy robe against the night chill.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Nine hours. I was about to send men to inquire. You look... different. What happened in that room, my husband?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The candle burns. Outside, Rome sleeps, unknowing. Tomorrow, everything changes.

encounters.recap: After sealing the papal documents for reform, Juan, Eugenius, and Parentucelli finalize plans for tomorrow's public announcement. They arrange for Castilian soldiers to secure the Camera, with Parentucelli taking charge of protecting the records and treasury. Juan returns late at night to the Palazzo di San Marco, where Lucia waits, noting the change in her husband after this historic day of church reform planning.
